column1: Hartford, CT - The Connecticut Department of Public Health (DPH) is warning residents of health concerns associated with flood water and that severe flooding has the potential to contaminate drinking water sources and lead to sewage back-ups in homes.
With record flooding predicted in the state from Hurricane Sandy, DPH is advising residents to assume that all flood water is contaminated and to avoid contact with any flood water.
Flood water may contain viruses, bacteria and germs which could lead to severe illness.

All food and water that has come into contact with flood water should be considered contaminated and discarded. This includes packaged food items in plastic, paper, cardboard, cloth, and similar containers that may have been water damaged, as well as beverage containers with screw-caps, snap lids, crimped caps (soda bottles), twist caps, flip tops, and home canned foods, as these tops cannot be disinfected appropriately. For information on cleanup after a flood, go to www.ct.gov/dph/floods.

With unprecedented tidal surge anticipated, some public water systems may be compromised. Listen for water reports from your public water supplier or local authorities to find out if your water is safe. If an advisory has been issued concerning contaminated water, or if you notice any unusual changes to the water (color, taste or odor), precautionary measures, such as using boiled or bottled water, should be taken until you are advised otherwise.

Homeowners in flooded areas whose private wells have flooded should consider their wells contaminated. Contaminated wells should be disinfected before use. If you notice any unusual changes to the water (color, taste or odor), precautionary measures, such as using boiled or bottled water, should be taken until testing is done to find if contamination is present in the water supply. For information on disinfecting wells, go to www.ct.gov/dph/floods.

If there is a boil water notice or advisory, or if you suspect that your water supply is contaminated, boiled or bottled water should be used when cooking, washing fruits and vegetables, brushing teeth, or making baby formula. You should also use boiled or bottled water to wash your hands when cooking. Adults and older children do not need to use boiled water to shower or bathe, but should try not to swallow or get any untreated water into their mouth. Infants, toddlers, the elderly, and people with severely compromised immune systems should be bathed using boiled or bottled water.

You can safely boil your water by bringing it to a rolling boil for one minute. A rolling boil means that there are very large bubbles in the water, making the water move very quickly. Make sure the water does not have any floating pieces in it before you boil it.

Flooding can cause sewage back-ups into basements and onto private property. Sewage contains bacteria, viruses, and other germs that can cause disease and make a contaminated house unfit for living. Your health may be impacted if a sewage back-up occurs in your home. Sewage back-ups can also contaminate your private drinking well water.
If you have a sewage back-up in your home:
Turn off the power if there is standing water or the possibility of electrical wires coming into contact with water or wet materials.
Keep all children and pets away from the sewage.
Wear rubber gloves when handling anything contaminated with sewage. Wash hands immediately afterwards. Never touch raw sewage with bare hands.
If your home is served by a municipal sewer system, call your local sewer department (town public works department or water pollution control authority) or go to their website.
If your home has a septic system, call your local health department for advice about how to dispose of the water/sewage.
For more information on what to do if you have a sewage back-up in your home and cleanup after a flood, go to www.ct.gov/dph/floods.
For updated information on Hurricane Sandy, go to www.ct.gov/sandy.

column1:
Some residents in Flower Mound will experience an interruption in water service on Monday, October 29, 2012.  Residents living on and west of Post Oak road will be the ones affected.

The interruption is expected to be between 9a.m. and 8p.m.

According to a news release issued by the town of Flower Mound, the interruption is due to crews connecting a new water pipeline section associated with the future Cross Timbers (FM 1171) road improvement project.

The Texas Commission on Environmental Quality requires the city to issue a boil water notification until service has been restored. Those who get water from another source and not the city will not be affected.

You can find complete details on the notification here.

column1: <div class="" withRelated right"" id=""WNStoryBody""><span id=""WNStoryDateline"">POPE COUNTY, IL (KFVS) -
A boil water order for Millstone Water District customers in Pope and Hardin counties has been lifted.

According to Plant Operator Jerry Palmer, Millstone customers in Pope County from Homburg Road on Route 146 to Golconda, Bay City, Eichorn, Rosiclaire and Job Corps are no longer under a boil water order.
Lab samples confirmed the water is safe for drinking and cooking purposes.

column1: Motorists in the Pine Valley area are urged to avoid certain areas due to a water main break.
WILMINGTON, NC (WECT) – Crews with the Cape Fear Public Utility Authority are on scene at a water main break in the Pine Valley area.
According to CFPUA officials, the intersection of Henry H. Waters and JEB Stuart Drives has been closed while crews work on repairs.
Motorists traveling in this area are advised to use alternate routes around the work zone.
A precautionary boil water advisory will be issued and hand delivered to affected customers.
Crews expect the work to be completed by 4:00 pm.

Water officials are urging Treasure Island residents to boil water or visit a site with access to potable water this morning following a water main break that may have led to contaminated water pipes.

The rupture occurred between 5 p.m. and 6 p.m. Friday, leaving the island without water service overnight, according to water officials.

Yerba Buena Island was not affected.

Water service has since been restored, however tap water is not anticipated to be safe for drinking until Monday morning when repairs and testing are complete, according to water officials.

Water officials are advising those on Treasure Island to boil tap water before drinking as a precautionary measure until repairs are completed.

Tap water on Yerba Buena Island is safe to drink.

Just before 10 a.m., emergency personnel advised that potable water is available at 12th Street and Avenue D on the island. Residents may bring a clean water container that can carry up to 5 gallons.

Those who do not purify tap water before drinking risk a stomach or intestinal illness from contaminated water, according to water officials.

More information about the Treasure Island water emergency may be found at sfwater.org/index.aspx?page=587

CHARLESTON, W.Va. -- West Virginia American Water has issued a boil-water advisory for approximately 100 customers in the Peytona and Midway areas of Boone County. The advisory area includes W.Va. 3 from Hemlock Drive south to the railroad crossing, King Street, Russell Avenue, Peytona Road, Roundbottom Road, Renee Drive and Baxter Drive, the Racine Hill area and any other customers in nearby areas who have experienced an interruption in water service Monday. The advisory follows a water main break.The West Virginia Department of Health and Human Resources has issued a boil-water advisory for Dameron, Arnett, Rock Creek, Dry Creek, Naoma, Horse Creek, Sundial, Edwight, Stickney, Montcoal, Birchton, Eunice, Pettus, Leevale, Jarrolds, Valley and Sandy Bottom areas of the Glen White-Trap Hill Public Service District. FORT EDWARD -- A limited number of homes in the village will be under a boil-water order for at least two days following a water main break on Mechanic Street.
Village officials said between 90 and 95 homes were without water while the leak was being repaired.
Because the work lasted more than four hours, state regulations require the water pass two daily tests before the boil-water order will be lifted. The earliest it can be lifted is Wednesday.
The streets involved included Mechanic, Beverly, Seminary, Oak, the single home on Pickett Drive and two other individual homes, 30 Marion and 2 Thornwood Drive.
Officials informed residents using the county’s reverse 911 phone system.
